newsitem.title: COSTA RICA: Sterilized banana workers make plea to Clinton.
newsitem.headline: Sterilized banana workers make plea to Clinton.

text.p: Costa Rican banana workers who claim to have been sterilised by a U.S.-made pesticide openly pleaded with U.S. President Bill Clinton on Thursday to allow them to sue U.S. companies in U.S. courts.

Clinton is in Costa Rica for a summit with six Central American nations and the Dominican Republic. A White House spokeswoman said officials had yet to receive the letter but were aware of the complaint through press reports.

Bananas are Costa Rica's top foreign currency earner after tourism and an important export for many of the other nations attending the summit with Clinton -- Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduras, Nicaragua, Belize and the Dominican Republic.

Lawyer Alvaro Montero, who represents some of the 8,000 affected Costa Rican banana workers, said certain U.S. judges have barred his clients from suing U.S. companies in U.S. courts, which Montero called a violation of international law, citing five international conventions.

The controversy surrounds dibromochloropropane, or DBCP, which is banned in the United States. Critics say it causes sterlization, birth defects and environmental damage and may cause cancer. The pesticide is used on banana planations to ward off microscopic worms.

The workers have targeted the Dow Chemical, Shell Oil -- a unit of Royal Dutch/Shell -- and Occidental Petroleum along with Del Monte Fruit, Chiquita Brands and Dole Food for their various roles in developing and distributing the pesticide.

"Mr. President, as the one in charge of international relations in your country, you are responsible for making sure international treaties signed by the United States are complied with," Montero wrote.

International human rights workers who have taken up their cause claim thousands more workers from throughout Central America, the Caribbean, Africa and the Philippines have been adversely affected by DBCP.
Opponents of DBCP claim it was dumped on the Third World after its use was restricted in the United States.
Banana workers who spray the chemical over long periods of time say it enters their bodies through the skin and lungs, and that their urine smells of DBCP when the day is done.
